content.content: TLDR  Restart Burn Immediately   Option I: Hard Burn  Restart previous burn model with all inefficiencies.    Option II: Slow Burn  Burn at a reduced rate until we develop something better.     Restore Revenue Distribution Narrative  Burn until we have a concrete system to replace it.   Retain Investors Retain our Community & Talent   Overview In my opinion, putting aside my own personal shituation, shutting off the burn at a market cycle bottom was arguably one of the worst decisions we have made as a community to date. I will admit that are benefits to operating on a model that prioritizes reinvesting into growth during early stages rather than distributing revenue. It works for Amazon, and it works for many others as well. It may even work for us as well. Unfortunately, in practice, what we’ve done is turn off the only revenue distribution model we had… at a market cycle bottom. I know it was not perfect. It was inefficient, gameable, and didn’t perceptibly return value to MKR holders. Still imperfect as it was, people liked it. I liked it, and so did many others. As it stands, we have no concrete plan in place to distribute revenue. We removed what we had but are yet to replace it with anything new. Our community members and long-term investors are dropping out like flies. Some from 2018 PTSD, others have just lost faith in our governance community’s ability to deliver. We still have revenue, though! It may be less than before, but that’s expected during a period of market contraction and a general reduction in appetite to borrow and take on risk.  This is temporary!  No market can maintain consistent negative perp funding indefinitely. A majority of market players taking one side of a position for pushing six months now are inevitably going to get rekt. It’s rare that everyone is right.  At some point there will be a new funding cycle. People will get excited and borrow again. I’m not concerned about our temporary dip in revenue. The burn is what retained many of our investors for years. Even through Black Thursday, one of the most challenging times we had to face as a community, we held through it. Yes, we did mint, and MKR suffered but has recovered since. As it stands, though, we still have the mint risk but no burn to counterbalance it. This puts many of our holders into a very tricky state of having to weigh underwriting huge codified downside risk with no clear promise of upside. It becomes very easy to justify classifying MKR as an overly risk-on asset during liquidity crunches. Dumping during times of uncertainty is a no-brainer. As each individual dumps, we increasingly expose ourselves to a governance attack. At this point, the illiquidity of MKR may be the only thing saving us from a nefarious actor buying up enough MKR to control the system. None of us want to see this, and given how essential Maker and DAI are to this space and the world in general, it would be disastrous to allow ourselves to capitulate into handing over control of this protocol to bad actors. It’s not just about “wen moon?” or "number go up blz! Ya, I’d like that… since I’m super rekt right now… “can dev do something?” I wish… but tha’s not important. MakerDAO is genuinely in a place to change the world for the better. We deliver untold value and self-sovereignty to people in parts of the world that have nowhere else to turn to but DAI. Do any of us really expect them to use UST or USDT? They want… no… they NEED DAI. We need to retain our community at all costs to succeed. Complacency right now will be the end of us.   Burn So, in part… I understand why we shut off the burn. We had extreme slippage, and it appeared like we were just wasting money. The slippage was terrible, yes. It’s a consequence of our community kicking the can down the road about implementing any sort of marketing-making scheme… but it is what it is for now. If we burn, it will be with slippage. The other argument for not burning was that we need to save DAI in the treasury to accumulate for a true Black Swan. Maybe??  It just so happened that as that sentiment creeped in and we decided to pause burning, it was at the exact bottom (so far, knock on wood) for crypto. Yes, I know Macro fell more later on. Anyway, we got all flustered and cash happy at arguably the worst time to hoard cash. Although it may seem like everything is dumping, as it stands, BTC and ETH are just holding a steady uptrend. (Yes, I know it looks ready to go to zero any day now… but how else does a market shake everyone out?) Basically, we started hoarding cash when it was time to deploy. As the market continues to appear worse and worse, we continue to hoard. Regrettably, no amount of hoarding will protect us from a Black Swan if one is coming. The SB will be drained instantly, MKR will be minted… and nice knowing all of you! At these prices, though, do we REALLY lack so much faith in our project that we wouldn’t buyback and burn when it’s undervalued by at least two orders? Finally, IMO, all price action below $2,000 MKR can be directly attributed to removing the burn.  Burn Options There are several ways we can restart burning.  Option I Restart the old burn mechanism immediately, with all inefficencies and just accept the losses to slippage.  Puase burning when we enter a new funding cycle and/or once a new tokenomics model is developed, has community approval, and is ready to be implemented.   Option II Restart burning at a slower rate. Instead of a hard burn with high slippage, burn slower.  Puase burning when we enter a new funding cycle and/or once a new tokenomics model is developed, has community approval, and is ready to be implemented.   Option III Assuming we do keep a burn model, at least in part, down the road, we can design a very efficient burn model based on sentiment counter trading. I’s not very complicated. I’ve tried proposing it a long time ago, but it didn’t seem to gain traction. The basic premise is to accumulate DAI for Aggressive Growth during manic market phases, and burn during fear and capitulation phases. These phases are fairly easy to identify and don’t require much data. If we do opt to retain any kind of burn model, I would be happy to contribute here.  Not listed in poll.      Restart the Burn?     Yes I: Burn MKR with all the DAI in the Surplus Buffer above the $54M threshold. (Borrowed from @JustinCase)  Yes II: Burn MKR at a reduced rate to mitigate slippage. Details TBD in a discussion.  No: Burning is inefficient, a waste of capital, and its value add is negative or imperceptible. The decision to pause burning has already been made. Abstain     0 voters     This poll will run until May 12th. 2022-05-01T00:00:00Z→2022-05-12T11:00:00Z If successful, an on-chain vote will be held to confirm the changes.  Next Steps  If we do opt to temporarily (or permanently?) restart the burn, whether in part or in full, we should focus on fully developing a new tokenomics and revenue distribution model complete and ready to go for a seamless transition from one paradigm to the next. Everyone should put a post-it on their screen, or tattoo onto their forehead: “Never again switch up a narrative at market cycle bottom.”  It’s great to experiment with new ideas, but save that for the euphoric stage of the market. There’s a lot more forgiveness in those times.     Final Thoughts I know the burn model we had wasn’t perfect, but I hope I’m not talking to a wall here. I want to see Maker thrive. If there’s something so much better we can implement right now, then sure… but we’re notorious for moving slow. Aggravating? of course… but it’s how we’ve built our reputation. Every change and upgrade is checked twelve times before being implemented. We build to last, but let’s not bleed our talent and community.

content.content: I advocate adding a new, separate, very simple burn module. It has 2 parameters: Minimum Surplus Buffer, and Minimum Flap Delay. Example parameters:  Minimum Surplus Buffer: 50m Dai Minimum Delay: 36 hours  This means that any time the surplus buffer is above 50m and no flap auction has been started from this module for at least 36 hours, anyone can kick off a flap auction. Other than the different kickoff conditions the flap auctions would be identical to the current ones. This gives MakerDAO the ability to set a minimum rate of MKR burn so long as the Surplus Buffer does not fall below the specified level. Given the sample parameters above, this would burn 7.3m Dai/year, at a steady pace, keeping the burn alive without putting a cap on Surplus Buffer growth.

content.content: I think a small, slow burn like the option I voted for is great. Especially at these prices.

It would be interesting to get a sense if Maker community members keen to restart the burn would support a ‘buyback and make’ model as an alternative (credit: Stop Burning Tokens – Buyback and Make Instead — Placeholder. ) A ‘buyback and make’ approach shares similar benefits to burning (by buying MKR off the open market, the price should increase) but provides a lot more flexibility. Rather than burning the MKR without adding value to the protocol, we could put it to use in a range of productive ways. For instance, we could automatically add liquidity for MKR, or offer the bought-back MKR as grants or incentives, while still taking advantage of the market lows as @aburban90 has detailed.  image1657×1667 234 KB  There might be zero interest in this, but it could be worth discussing as a sort of midground option where we can have buybacks and still continue to invest in growth. We should carefully consider whether possible changes will handicap the momentum of plans like the Aggressive Growth Strategy or A North Star - DAI as the Destination that will take Maker to the next level. More generally, it’s great to see a range of perspectives on the forum, and see an engaged community who cares about Maker considering and debating all possible options. This is what decentralised governance is all about!

content.content: Matt_NZ:  ‘buyback and make’ model   I would support this. It may very well be better than a burn. Buyback MKR from market, and fund an LP, reducing circulating supply while simultaneously increasing MKR liquidity and using it to generate yield from swap fees. My one issue is… how long would it take to architect? How long would it take to get community alignment? If we’re talking months…  Nevertheless, I do like it. Regardless… MKR under $2k… I struggle to see a reason not to be nitro-burning in some capacity. If we can get “Buyback and Make” up and running in a week? Then I’m all for it. If not, we still have the old burner ready to go.     aburban90:  Green is pure market panic and capitulation, max out burn rate.   Markets stay irrational for only so long. Those “Nitro Burn” periods I highlighted above… they’re fleeting. Sometimes you get a week, sometimes a couple of months. In short, you don’t get much time. Unless we, as a community, believe MKR is worthless and going to zero or something… don’t see why we wouldn’t burn here (or buyback & make).

content.content: I want the burn back at some point but I also know this is a point of contention and I’m not sure it’s good for us to bring it back up so quickly while all the growth initiatives are in focus. The burn works best when you have a lot of earnings to consistently plow back into the protocol.  The problem is that in order to grow, we have been increasing spending and reducing earnings.  So we have less cash flow to allocate to the burn and we’re preparing to either borrow or dilute in order to get a 250k or 300k SB.  So to restart the burn, you’re talking about either changing the growth plan or basically borrowing to buy MKR because anything you spend to burn is going to be needed to be borrowed back in order to get the SB we’re targeting. I’m not exactly surprised MKR’s value is dropping because in general riskier assets are getting hit harder in this market.  As you pivot to growth, there will be increasing execution risk and you’ll have to start proving yourself with increased revenue from all these RWA efforts.  To me, the ship has sailed on growth since we’re just not going to be offloading all these new expenses.  If token value really gets cheap, I think you could argue for directly buying and burning with the intention to reissue at a better price…but I’m not sure we’re really there yet.  Annual stability fees are 75.5 mil and you’re still at a 1.4 billion market cap.  You’ve been stuck without revenue growth (even decreasing numbers) for a good amount of time now and spending is up.  But your one saving grace is that you’re still profitable and that means you should stay solvent barring catastrophic circumstances. What MKR really needs more than a buyback program is to show increasing revenue that proves its growth strategy.  When investors see that, I’m certain they’ll be ready to jump back in.  No one is going to jump in for the buy and burn if the earnings keep decreasing because when you get to 0, there will be no more buying whether we want it or not.

content.content: I respect your thought-out response. I agree, though. On paper, burning from a dwindling treasury seems ludicrous. We have about $70M in the SB. The market is contracting, revenue is falling, and our expenses seem to be getting out of hand… it’s doom and gloom in every direction. Not just for us, but for everyone in every market and at every project.     Traster_Tray:  I want the burn back at some point…   At which point exactly? When there is more clarity in the market? When uncertainty has subsided, and things are going well? It may be ironic, but that’s precisely when we should not burn. That would be the time to build the treasury.     Traster_Tray:  If token value really gets cheap, I think you could argue for directly buying and burning with the intention to reissue at a better price.   What exactly would you define as “really gets cheap”? Clearly, $1400 isn’t cheap enough… is it $1200? $900? $500? How many more of us will capitulate on the way down to those levels (if we even get there). Will we even have a team left by then? We can pretend all we want that price doesn’t matter. Everyone will stay because they love the project and it’s their passion, etc. That’s a fantasy. Everyone responds to what’s going on in their own way, each with individual risk tolerances. We are already beginning to suffer the brain drain of those that have mentally checked out. They feel their passions and efforts have been for nothing, especially when they look around and see their peers abandoning them. I refuse to capitulate but watching everyone else do it while I sit through the pain is not the most rewarding feeling tbh. Yes, I’m grateful for the support I receive from many in our incredible community, but everyone has their limits. If we continue to pretend the price drop is not a factor, we will inevitably continue to bleed talent. Retaining talent, retaining our community, retaining our investors… that should be, IMO, a priority. Without them, we cannot succeed. Also, if we allow the price to fall far enough, we truly begin to expose ourselves to a true governance attack. MakerDAO is unique in this space. We’re the bedrock of DeFi.I can imagine all kinds of nefarious parties that would love nothing more than to execute a hostile takeover. From that, we will not recover.     Traster_Tray:  I’m not exactly surprised MKR’s value is dropping because in general riskier assets are getting hit harder in this market.   There’s nothing to be surprised about the drop right now. Any investor is underwriting $10b of mint risk if we have another solvency crisis. The counterbalance in return? It used to be the burn, but right now? Nothing.     Traster_Tray:  What MKR really needs more than a buyback program is to show increasing revenue that proves its growth strategy.   I’m all for a buyback & make program (if it’s ready to go live)… and I’m also all for an Aggressive Growth strategy… but there’s a time and a place to pivot to that. Right now? Global sentiment is clearly biased towards hoarding cash, arguably to euphoric levels. Of course, we can adopt that mentality ourselves and follow the masses… but, in my experience, I tend to find it’s more common that everyone is wrong all at once.  Call1024×768 118 KB   I would call the bluff.   The goal of restarting the burn here is to signal to the community and our remaining investors that we are not abandoning them. That we will honor the original revenue distribution model we had while we work on implementing a better model in the future. I understand that we can only burn so much with the cash we have on hand, but the signaling is most important. If we had focused on growing the treasury instead of burning during the manic phases of the market, the situation would be different right now… but it was it is.  As it stands, it appears that this vote will be passing with Option II. This leaves us with about $20m to burn. I suppose we can employ a DCA-type burn? It’s challenging to place an exact timeline, but… I would probably lean towards a constant daily burn that we continue to deploy until ETH breaks above $3800-4000. In an optimistic scenario, we could see that by mid-late May, at which point, we would taper down the burn. 0f course, that assumes market expansion, which implies more revenue as people borrow more, so we’d have more revenue to burn even harder (assuming mania hasn’t set in). If my math is correct, we should burn about:  $500-700k MKR per day      Traster_Tray:  Borrowing to buy MKR   I never considered this… sounds risky. I think other protocols have done this or do this. My gut tells me to shy away from this, but I would follow @Primoz’s advice if he believes this is a good idea.

content.content: That, ser, is a very good point. I hate it when the better becomes the enemy of the good.

I recommend against burning at current point in time; We need high amount of dai in SB;  To support safe expansion of new products like new vault types, MCD on other domains and D3Ms (we must sustain a potential exploit of counterparty protocols which seem to occur on a weekly basis these days) Community seems to favor the idea of spending dai in SB for speculative purposes, which will lower already small SB compared to DCs of D3Ms in terms of market risk neutral assets  Do we know for certain that MKR is dropping more than crypto market or tech stocks in general, which would suggest current price movements are a result of some asset specific factor such as lack of burn mechanism? This would be extremely surprising to me, because the majority of other DeFi projects have been doing the opposite of burning for the last two year - expending supply via airdrops or liquidity mining. If they are out performing MKR doesn’t this mean we should focus more on growth instead of burn? It could also be true that the burn mechanism is completely irrelevant to the price movement as other factors carry much higher weight. Let’s assume that MKR is dropping faster than the market. This essentially means that investors think other assets are a better opportunity. Turning burn back on would only give them exit liquidity and ability to sell at a better price and protocol burning less MKR in the end. Financial markets and the global economy are currently in a very uncertain situation;  Due to covid mandates, we have seen the largest expansion of money in modern history which had a large impact on financial asset prices including crypto, which is now in the phase of correction as seen with many stocks. Due to different reasons (money expansion, supply chain issues, economic sanctions vs Russia) inflation rate is extremely high - majority of developed economies are experiencing negative real growth rate. When recession cycle hits, things will get much worse Interest rates are on the rise which will lower growth rate and increase possibility of recession We are on the brink of largest geopolitical conflict in the modern era  We might be far from the market bottom and we should be prepared for this.

content.content: Hey @aburban90, Appreciate in initiative here and you’ve already generated quite a lot of discussion. However I would recommend taking a look through our Guide to the Signaling Process. In particular, we should clean up the actual voting and next steps. As far as the vote options go there are a couple concerns:  Vote options need to presented neutrally. People might have a different reason for voting No other than you’ve attached to the poll, making the voting potentially confusing. This is why we generally recommend signaling on a single issue, with the vote options being Yes, No, and Abstain. Options should be clearly labeled and a direct following of your summary. Lowering the Surplus Buffer to a maximum of 54M DAI is a fine option to have, but it should be referenced in your pro and con arguments above, rather than just introduced in the poll option.  I know it’s a pain to restart the vote, but we do want to make sure that we have an accurate result when the voting closes. Happy to lend a hand if needed.

I’d recommend we burn when our P/E ratio becomes respectable again (either via earnings or via price action) and if Risk is satisfied that we have enough to cover serious protocol issues. content.content: So I’m getting the feeling that the impetus behind this is the price action so let me show you why price might not look as cheap as you might think.  MKR’s revenues hit around 150 mil December last year.  What’s interesting is that expenses had also ramped up quite a bit last half of the year and the price actually peaked earlier than the revenue peak.  This is because markets are forward looking and you could say the market predicted the peak.  The price around this time was only around 2300-2600. Right now our fee revenue is now down to 75 mil and although it has stabilized here for awhile, if the crypto markets go further down, these fees will get hurt as well.  So what investors see is the opposite of growth.  Valuation wise, you’re over 18 times sales and depending on what you think our expenses are at maybe 35-40 times earnings.  Maybe these ratios should be lower if you factor liquidation income.  But 18 times sales is expensive in this market for even adequately growing businesses (look at ratios for tdoc, zm, docu) so you’re really only where you are because of earnings and a decently strong balance sheet with no debt.  You might be held up a little by people who see and believe the potential of the RWA push and vision.  But if revenues continue downward and earnings dry up, I can easily envision a much harder drop. Back in December, I wanted capital to be returned because we had so much money coming in, it was more a question of where the money would go.  But now, we make much less so even if you turn the burn back on, you’re going to get weeks of nothing when the big expenses get incurred on the SB.  Plus the SB is a critical component of growth plans so returning capital might be seen as detrimental to growth.  The problem right now is the growth trend…not the loss of capital return. All that being said, I could see value in a partial burn because it shows the intention to return/share capital.  It means if we do get growth, people can see potential for bigger burns.  But right now, a partial burn, depending on how it’s setup, would barely cover the mkr being vested by all the CUs so it’s really only a symbolic gesture until growth returns.  Mkr supply still goes down because we use mkr in the treasury but eventually that will run out and you’re going to be issuing the vesting mkr.
